body_html:
@apaszke I want to say two more things.

  1. torch.add(input, value=1, other, out=None) doesn't look like a Pythonic signature. Default value should always come last.
  2. out is keyword only in pytorch but not in numpy, and this difference can confuse people. In addition, this keyword only behavior is not well documented.

I can help with 2 by a PR. Not sure what to do with 1.
body_text:
@apaszke  I want to say two more things.

torch.add(input, value=1, other, out=None) doesn't look like a Pythonic signature. Default value should always come last.
out is keyword only in pytorch but not in numpy, and this difference can confuse people. In addition, this keyword only behavior is not well documented.

I can help with 2 by a PR. Not sure what to do with 1.
body:
@apaszke  I want to say two more things.

1. `torch.add(input, value=1, other, out=None)` doesn't look like a Pythonic signature. Default value should always come last.
2. `out` is keyword only in pytorch but not in numpy, and this difference can confuse people. In addition, this keyword only behavior is not well documented.

I can help with 2 by a PR. Not sure what to do with 1.
